title: 111_hr1505
content: The "Birth Parent Assistance Act of 2009" aims to enhance post-placement services and counseling for birth parents who have placed a child for adoption, as well as identify ways to improve these services. It authorizes post-adoption services for birth parents. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide post-legal adoption services and counseling for birth parents through eligible entities such as States, local governmental entities, and public or private agencies. Services include individual, group, and family counseling. The eligible entities will provide post-legal adoption services, including individual, group, and family counseling. They must submit an application to the Secretary detailing how they will use funds to achieve the purposes of the program. The Secretary will also require reports from each eligible entity. The Secretary requires eligible entities receiving grants to submit reports on services provided. Services must supplement, not supplant, other funds. Technical assistance will be provided to eligible entities. The Secretary will provide technical assistance to eligible entities receiving grants for adoption-related services. They will coordinate services with other activities and evaluate their implementation and effectiveness. Different post-placement services will be identified. The Secretary will evaluate the implementation and effectiveness of adoption-related services and identify ways to improve post-placement services for birth parents. A report will be submitted to Congress within 3 years of the Act's enactment. Authorization of appropriations for the Secretary of Health and Human Services: $30,000,000 for fiscal year 2010 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2011 through 2014. Amounts remain available until expended.
